title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #815 asks whether 'degree 3 critical' graphs must contain cycles of all lengths k ≥ 3. These are graphs with n vertices, 2n-2 edges, where every proper induced subgraph has minimum degree ≤ 2. DISPROVED by Narins-Pokrovskiy-Szabó (2017) who found such graphs with no C_23.

title: Minimum Degree
content: The minimum degree of a graph is the smallest degree among all vertices. We define it using Finset.min' over the image of the degree function. This is key to the 'degree 3 critical' condition.

title: Degree 3 Critical Graphs
content: A graph is 'degree 3 critical' if: (1) it has 2n-2 edges for n vertices, and (2) every proper induced subgraph has minimum degree ≤ 2. These graphs are on the boundary of having a '3-regular core' - they have enough edges for complexity but can't localize that structure.

title: Cycles in Graphs
content: A cycle of length k (C_k) is a closed walk of length k that doesn't repeat edges. We define ContainsCk using walks in Mathlib's SimpleGraph. The question is which cycle lengths must appear in degree 3 critical graphs.

title: The Erdős-Hajnal Conjecture
content: The conjecture: for all k ≥ 3 and sufficiently large n, every degree 3 critical graph on n vertices contains C_k. This would mean such graphs have rich cycle structure - containing ALL possible cycle lengths.

title: EFGS Short Cycles Theorem
content: Erdős-Faudree-Gyárfás-Schelp (1988) proved: every degree 3 critical graph on n ≥ 5 vertices contains C_3, C_4, AND C_5. So short cycles are guaranteed - the question was about longer ones.

title: EFGS Long Cycle Theorem
content: EFGS also proved: every degree 3 critical graph contains a cycle of length at least ⌊log₂ n⌋. This gives a lower bound on the longest cycle, but doesn't guarantee specific cycle lengths.

title: EFGS Upper Bound
content: EFGS showed there exist degree 3 critical graphs with no cycle longer than √n. This means not ALL long cycles are guaranteed - there's a gap between log₂(n) and √n.

title: Narins-Pokrovskiy-Szabó Counterexample
content: The key result (2017): for any N, there exists a degree 3 critical graph on ≥N vertices with NO cycle of length 23. This disproves the Erdős-Hajnal conjecture for k = 23.

title: The Formal Disproof
content: We prove ¬ErdosHajnalConjecture by contradiction: the conjecture would give N such that all large degree 3 critical graphs have C_23. But Narins-Pokrovskiy-Szabó provides such a graph on ≥N vertices WITHOUT C_23. Contradiction.

title: Open Problem: Even k
content: The counterexample uses k = 23 (odd). It remains OPEN whether degree 3 critical graphs must contain C_k for all even k ≥ 4. Perhaps even and odd cycle lengths behave differently in these graphs.

title: Understanding the Condition
content: Why 'degree 3 critical'? A graph with 2n-2 edges has average degree ~4. The subgraph condition means no dense core exists. These graphs balance: enough edges for complexity, but structure can't be localized. Named because they're minimal graphs where some vertex has degree ≥3.

title: Construction Idea
content: How does the counterexample work? Narins-Pokrovskiy-Szabó use recursive structure and careful local analysis to build graphs satisfying |E| = 2|V| - 2 and the subgraph condition while avoiding any 23-cycle. The number 23 is the smallest odd k where their technique works.

title: Summary
content: Erdős Problem #815 is DISPROVED. While degree 3 critical graphs always contain C_3, C_4, C_5 (EFGS), and cycles of length log₂(n) to √n, specific longer lengths like 23 can be avoided. Timeline: 1988 EFGS positive results, 1991 Erdős states problem, 2017 Narins-Pokrovskiy-Szabó disproof.
